user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_try_alloc:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_try_alloc (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                    size_t size,
                    size_t *required_bytes)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
  { /* size is too close to SIZE_MAX, very unlikely */
    *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
  {
    mhd_assert ((pool->end - pool->pos) == \
                ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->end - pool->pos));
    if (asize <= pool->end)
      *required_bytes = asize - (pool->end - pool->pos);
    else
      *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  *required_bytes = 0;
  ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
  pool->end -= asize;
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_try_alloc:
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (((n)+(ALIGN_SIZE-1))/(ALIGN_SIZE)*(ALIGN_SIZE))
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE(n) ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n)
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY(pointer, size) (void)0
...
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no use of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Typical compiler extensions that would trigger Rule 1.2 (and that I specifically looked for) include: GCC/Clang __attribute__ annotations, __asm__ or inline assembly, statement-expressions ({ ... }) as an expression, typeof, nested functions, binary literals or other non-standard literal forms, compiler builtins (e.g. __builtin_*), Microsoft-specific __declspec, token-pasting or concatenation tricks used as extensions, or other constructs explicitly documented as extensions by compilers. None of these appear in the function or the related macros/struct. The code uses standard C identifiers and standard library types (size_t, uint8_t, bool, SIZE_MAX) and only standard preprocessor features (macros, backslash-newline continuation). Note: identifiers or macros beginning with an underscore followed by a capital letter (e.g. _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY) are reserved by the implementation, but that is a reservation of identifiers rather than a compiler language extension; it does not by itself constitute use of a documented compiler extension per Rule 1.2. Therefore there are no fragments to report for investigation under Rule 1.2.
